prior_works.title: PSI: Exact Symbolic Inference for Probabilistic Programs
prior_works.authors: Andreas Gehr, Sasa Misailovic, Martin Vechev
prior_works.role: Exact inference for probabilistic programs via symbolic methods
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Genfer directly builds on PSI’s agenda of fully-automated exact inference for probabilistic programs, but replaces PSI’s heavy reliance on computer algebra with probability generating functions (PGFs) and automatic differentiation to handle infinite supports and continuous priors more robustly.

prior_works.title: DICE: Exact Inference for Discrete Probabilistic Programs
prior_works.authors: Robert A. Holtzen, Guy Van den Broeck, Todd Millstein
prior_works.role: Symbolic/exact inference for discrete PPLs through program transformations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Like DICE, the paper targets exact inference for discrete program models, but it advances the state of the art by using PGFs as a compact closed-form representation to compute posteriors and moments (via derivatives), extending exactness to many infinite-support settings without bespoke symbolic algebra.

prior_works.title: On Probabilistic Inference by Weighted Model Counting
prior_works.role: Foundational exact inference via knowledge compilation and algebraic evaluation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The PGF-based approach echoes WMC’s idea of compiling models into algebraic objects for exact evaluation; here, PGFs play the role of the compiled representation enabling exact probability and moment extraction for program-defined discrete models.

prior_works.title: Weighted Model Integration: A Logical Approach to Probabilistic Inference with Arithmetic Constraints
prior_works.authors: Vaishak Belle, Kristian Kersting, Luc De Raedt (and later variants with Michele Passerini)
prior_works.role: Exact inference for hybrid discrete–continuous models
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper addresses hybrid settings akin to WMI but offers an alternative computational path: PGFs plus Taylor-based automatic differentiation to handle continuous priors over discrete latent structures without resorting to piecewise symbolic integration.

prior_works.title: Analytic Combinatorics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The core insight—encoding distributions via generating functions and extracting probabilities and moments through derivatives—draws directly from analytic combinatorics, which the paper adapts to probabilistic program semantics.

prior_works.title: Abstraction, Refinement and Proof for Probabilistic Systems (pGCL)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By ensuring that PGF manipulation yields exact posterior probabilities and moments, the paper’s correctness arguments align with expectation/transformer-based semantics pioneered in pGCL, grounding the soundness of exact quantitative reasoning about programs.

prior_works.title: Evaluating Derivatives: Principles and Techniques of Algorithmic Differentiation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The method’s practical engine—extracting coefficients and moments via Taylor polynomials of PGFs—relies critically on AD foundations, enabling automation without computer algebra and thereby operationalizing the proposed inference pipeline.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s key contribution—exact Bayesian inference for discrete probabilistic programs (even with infinite supports and continuous priors) via probability generating functions (PGFs) and automatic differentiation—sits at the confluence of exact PPL inference, generating-function analysis, and AD. Prior systems like PSI and DICE established that exact, fully automated inference is feasible for discrete probabilistic programs by compiling programs into algebraic representations and applying symbolic manipulation. The present work adopts that ethos but replaces bespoke computer-algebra pipelines with PGFs as a uniform, closed-form representation of program-defined distributions, enabling direct computation of posteriors and higher moments by differentiation.
Analytic combinatorics provides the mathematical backbone: generating functions encode compositional structure (sums, products, branching), and derivatives recover probabilities and moments. This perspective dovetails with probabilistic program semantics from pGCL/expectation transformers, ensuring that the PGF calculus corresponds to exact quantitative semantics (probabilities, expectations, variances). On the hybrid side, Weighted Model Integration demonstrated exact inference with continuous priors over discrete/Boolean structure; the PGF approach advances this by supporting many infinite-support models and leveraging AD-driven Taylor polynomials rather than piecewise symbolic integration. Finally, automatic differentiation theory operationalizes the method, allowing Genfer to extract Taylor coefficients and factorial moments efficiently without general-purpose computer algebra. Together, these strands crystallize into a new, implementable pipeline—PGFs + AD—that generalizes prior exact PPL inference to broader discrete models with rigorous correctness and strong empirical performance.
